The '''2010 gang rapes in Cleveland, Texas''' were a series of acts of [[sexual violence]] committed by a group of adult men and teenage boys on an [[Minor (law)#United States|underage]] girl in the town of [[ Cleveland, Texas|Cleveland]], in [[Texas]], USA. ==Background== The victim was the 11-year old daughter of [[Mexicans|Mexican]] [[Immigration to the United States|immigrants]], living in [[Cleveland, Texas]], a "timber town"<ref name=worst>{{cite news |last1=Jarboe Russell|first1=Jan|date=July 2011 |title=The Worst Hard Time |url=https://www.texasmonthly.com/articles/the-worst-hard-time/ |dead-url=no |work=[[Texas Monthly]] |location=|archiveurl=|archivedate=|access-date=5 October 2018}}</ref> of about nine thousand people in the [[Greater Houston]] metropolitan area and [[Liberty County, Texas|Liberty County]]. Her father was a former [[construction worker]], unemployed at the time for a year and a half because of a back injury, while her mother was working making change in a [[Slot machine|slot game room]].<ref name=gq/>
The group of perpetrators included students at the local high school, two of whom were members of the basketball team and one the son of a school-board member, and persons with [[criminal record]]s, from [[Recreational drug use|selling drug]]s to [[robbery]] and, in one case, [[manslaughter]]. They ranged from [[Middle_school#United_States|middle school]]ers to one 27-year-old, at the time of the crime.<ref name=vicious>{{cite news |last1=McKinley|first1=James C. |date=8 March 2011 |title=Vicious Assault Shakes Texas Town |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/09/us/09assault.html?hp |dead-url=no |work=[[The New York Times]] |location=|archiveurl=|archivedate=|access-date=5 October 2018}}</ref> ==Discovery== On the Monday after [[Thanksgiving]] day, on 29 November 2010, a [[cell phone]] [[video clip]] with images of the sexual encounter between a group of males and a young female circulated in the cafeteria of Cleveland's high school. Some viewers recognized the girl as a [[Sixth grade#United States|6th grade]]r from the middle school next door.<ref name=gq>{{cite news |last1=Dobie|first1=Kathie |date=6 September 2011 |title=The Girl from Trails End|url=https://www.gq.com/story/texas-gang-rape-11-year-old-girl-story|dead-url=no |work=[[GQ]] |location=|archiveurl=|archivedate=|access-date=5 October 2018}}</ref> A friend of the girl told a teacher what he had seen in the cell-phone video, as a school-district spokeswoman subsequently stated, and the police were alerted.<ref name=sloppy>{{cite news |last1=Williams|first1=Mary Elizabeth |date=9 March 2011 |title=The New York Times’ sloppy, slanted child rape story |url=https://www.salon.com/2011/03/09/new_york_times_blames_11_year_old_rape_victim/|dead-url=no |work=[[Salon (website)|Salon]] |location=|archiveurl=|archivedate=|access-date=5 October 2018}}</ref><ref name=arrested>{{cite news |last1=Lozano|first1=Juan A. |date=9 March 2011 |title=18 arrested in assaults on 11-year-old Texas girl|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/41993963/ns/us_news-crime_and_courts/t/arrested-assaults--year-old-texas-girl/#.W7cNP2j7Tcu|dead-url=no |work=[[NBC News]] |location=|archiveurl=|archivedate=|access-date=5 October 2018}}</ref> ==Investigation== Police investigators identified and contacted the girl, whereupon she stated that, over the 2010 Thanksgiving holiday break, she was raped by a group of young men first at a house and then in a [[mobile home]]. According to a [[search warrant]] [[affidavit]] obtained by the media, police determined the video clip was recorded inside an abandoned mobile home on the city's northern outskirts, next to a [[Baptist church]].<ref name=arrested>{{cite news |last1=Lozano|first1=Juan A. |date=9 March 2011 |title=18 arrested in assaults on 11-year-old Texas girl|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/41993963/ns/us_news-crime_and_courts/t/arrested-assaults--year-old-texas-girl/#.W7cNP2j7Tcu|dead-url=no |work=[[NBC News]] |location=|archiveurl=|archivedate=|access-date=5 October 2018}}</ref> According to the subsequent, criminal [[indictment]]s, the girl was assaulted on four separate occasions: the first in September, followed by three more throughout the fall of 2010. In January 2011, she was removed by [[social worker]]s from her parents' home and taken to [[foster care]].<ref name=gq/>
The investigation stirred [[Racism in the United States|racial tensions]] on account of the defendants all being [[African-American]]s and the girl [[Hispanic]],<ref name=period>{{cite news |last1=Hopper|first1=Jessica |date=18 March 2011 |title=Texas Girl Allegedly Gang Raped Over Three Month Period |url=https://abcnews.go.com/US/cleveland-texas-girl-allegedly-raped-multiple-times-court/story?id=13167326|work=[[ABC News]] |location=|archiveurl=|archivedate=|access-date=5 October 2018}}</ref> in both the town and nationwide.<ref name=appear>{{cite news |last1=Martinez|first1=Edecio |date=5 April 2011 |title=Cleveland, Texas gang rape suspects appear in court |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/cleveland-texas-gang-rape-suspects-appear-in-court/|work=[[CBS News]] |location=|archiveurl=|archivedate=|access-date=5 October 2018}}</ref> The event was publicized nationwide in the States and also abroad.<ref name=paris>{{cite news |last1=Vely|first1=Yannick|date=9 March 2011 |title=Le Viol Collectif qui choque l’Amérique|url=https://www.parismatch.com/Actu/International/Le-viol-collectif-qui-choque-l-Amerique-146689|dead-url=no|language=French|trans-title=The Gang Rape that shocked America |work=[[Paris Match]] |location=|archiveurl=|archivedate=|access-date=5 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Freeman|first1=Hadley|author-link=Hadley Freeman|date=3 September 2013 |title=The painful lesson of the Cherice Moralez rape trial|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/sep/03/painful-lesson-cherice-moralez-rape|dead-url=no |work=[[The Guardian]] |location=|archiveurl=|archivedate=|access-date=5 October 2018}}</ref>
On Monday 4 April 2011, nineteen defendants appeared in the court of [[Liberty County, Texas|Liberty County]] district judge Mark Morefield for their [[arraignment]] hearing, with six of them pleading "not guilty."<ref name=appear/>
==Support for the accused== The ''[[New York Times]]''' first report<ref name=vicious/> focused on the impact of the crime on the Cleveland community.<ref group=note>On the 8 March NYT article, a hospital worker, who said she knew several of the defendants, was quoted: “It’s just destroyed our community. These boys have to live with this the rest of their lives.” Also quoted was the spokeswoman for the Cleveland Independent School District: “It’s devastating, and it’s really tearing our community apart. I really wish that this could end in a better light.” There were also quotes from local people who questioned the attitude of the victim's family, such as a neighbor of her parents: "Where was her mother? What was her mother thinking?”</ref> The report came under criticism for its alleged "sympathy" for the accused,<ref name=mj>{{cite news |last1=McCleland|first1=Mac |date=9 March 2011 |title=The New York Times’ Rape-Friendly Reporting|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2011/03/new-york-times-texas-rape/|dead-url=no |work=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] |location=|archiveurl=|archivedate=|access-date=5 October 2018}}</ref><ref name=nymag>{{cite news |last1=Amira|first1=Dan |date=11 March 2011 |title=A Lot of People in Cleveland, Texas, Blame 11-Year-Old for Being Raped|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2011/03/a_lot_of_people_in_cleveland_t.html|dead-url=no |work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] ''magazine'' |location=|archiveurl=|archivedate=|access-date=5 October 2018}}</ref><ref name=nation>{{cite news |last1= Cobb|first1= William Jelani|author-link=William Jelani Cobb|date=29 March 2011 |title=Cleveland, Texas and Gender Jim Crow |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2011/03/a_lot_of_people_in_cleveland_t.html|dead-url=no |work=[[The Nation]] |location=|archiveurl=|archivedate=|access-date=5 October 2018}}</ref> to the point where the newspaper sent another reporter back at the place<ref name=balance>{{cite news |last1=Brisbane|first1=Arthur S.|date=11 March 2011 |title=Gang Rape Story Lacked Balance |url=https://publiceditor.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/03/11/gang-rape-story-lacked-balance/?smid=fb-nytimes|dead-url=no |work=[[The New York Times]] |location=|archiveurl=|archivedate=|access-date=5 October 2018}}</ref> and published a self-critical article.<ref group=note>The 11 March NYT article stated: "The outrage [against the previous NYT report] is understandable. The story dealt with a hideous crime but addressed concerns about the ruined lives of the perpetrators without acknowledging the obvious: concern for the victim. While the story appeared to focus on the community’s reaction to the crime, it was not enough to simply report that the community is principally concerned about the boys and men involved – as this story seems to do. If indeed that is the only sentiment to be found in this community...it becomes important to report... as well [of] voices of professional authorities or dissenting community members who will at least address, and not ignore, the plight of the young girl involved."</ref>
[[Quanell X]], [[community leader]] and head of the [[New Black Panthers]], was an "outspoken critic" of the victim. In a [[press conference]] in front of a Cleveland church, he [[rhetorical question|asked rhetorically]] where the girl's parents were when this happened and why was "that child experiencing so much sex with so many African-American men." He also disputed the rape claims since, as he put it, the girl never actually yelled the word "rape" during the assault and did not make an "outcry" until after footage of the assault surfaced.<ref group=note>According to the ''[[Houston Press]]'' 2014 report, Quanell X claimed the investigation into the rape was being "run by the [[KKK]]" and stated to the [[African American]] community of the town: "We do not want someone with a malicious, racist motive to rid your community of an entire generation of black men."</ref> The media reported that the audience "cheered and hollered in agreement."<ref name=cheered>{{cite news |last1=Leicht|first1=Angelica|date=19 December 2014 |title=Why Does Quanell X Support Some Rape Victims But Shame Others?|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2011/03/a_lot_of_people_in_cleveland_t.html|dead-url=no |work=[[Houston Press]] |location=|archiveurl=|archivedate=|access-date=5 October 2018}}</ref>
[[Florida]] [[United States House of Representatives|representative]] [[Kathleen Passidomo]] proposed that the state should step in and regulate the wardrobe of young girls.<ref name=pasidomo>{{cite news |last1=Linkins|first1=Jason|date=13 March 2011 |title=In Wake Of Texas Gang Rape, Florida Lawmaker Proposes School Dress Code Legislation|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/16/texas-gang-rape-aftermath-florida-law_n_836841.html|dead-url=no |work=[[Huffington Post]] |location=|archiveurl=|archivedate=|access-date=5 October 2018}}</ref> Pasidomo referred to "an article about an 11 year old girl who was gang-raped in Texas by 18 young men because she was dressed like a 21-year-old [[prostitute]].”<ref group=note>Passidomo claimed that "it’s incumbent upon [the state] to create some areas where students can be safe in school and show up in proper attire, so what happened in Texas doesn’t happen to [Florida's] students.”</ref>
==Trials== In Texas, [[sexual assault]] against a [[Minor (law)#United States|person under 17 years of age]] is a second degree [[felony]], and [[aggravated sexual assault]] a first degree felony.<ref name=texaslaw>{{cite web |url=https://statutes.capitol.texas.gov/Docs/PE/htm/PE.22.htm|title=Penal Code - Title 5, Chapter 22: Assaultive Offenses|publisher=[[Texas Department of Criminal Justice]] |date=October 2017 |website=|access-date=7 October 2018}}</ref> Eventually, twenty-one persons were charged with crimes related to the gang rape.<ref name=four>{{cite news |date=21 September 2012 |title=Texas: Four Get 15-Year Sentences in Gang Rape of 11-Year-Old Girl|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/22/us/four-sentenced-in-gang-rape-of-11-year-old-texas-girl.html|dead-url=no |work=[[The New York Times]] |location=Associated Press|archiveurl=|archivedate=|access-date=6 October 2018}}</ref> Only two adult males requested trials, and juries handed each defendant a 99-year prison sentence. Eleven other adult males pleaded guilty to the charges against them and received 15-year sentences in exchange. All seven juveniles entered guilty pleas and received seven-year [[Probation|probated prison-sentences]].<ref name=final>{{cite news |last=Horswell |first=Cindy |date=11 October 2013|title=21st assailant sentenced in Cleveland gang rape|url=https://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/houston/article/21st-assailant-sentenced-in-Cleveland-gang-rape-4889262.php|dead-url=no |work=[[Houston Chronicle]] |location= |archiveurl= |access-date=6 October 2018}}</ref> The twenty-first and last defendant pleaded guilty after a year long investigation whereby a [[DNA profiling|DNA specimen]] identified him as being at the [[crime scene]]. The defendant received a reduced seven-year sentence in exchange for pleading guilty to [[Indecent exposure|indecently exposing]] himself to a child. All defendants sentenced to prison would be [[Sex offender registry|registered]] as [[sex offender]]s for ten years after completing the sentence.<ref name=final/>
==Aftermath== When the investigation started, the victim's family moved to another town after police detectives told the parents that they were in danger,<ref name=nightmare>{{cite news |last1=McKinley|first1=James C.|last2=Goode|first2=Erica |date=28 March 2011 |title=3-Month Nightmare Emerges in Rape Inquiry |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/29/us/29texas.html |dead-url=no |work=[[The New York Times]] |location=|archiveurl=|archivedate=|access-date=5 October 2018}}</ref> while the girl who was reported as raped was placed by the [[Child Protective Services]] in the care of the Girls' Haven in [[Beaumont, Texas]]. In December 2011, she ran away from the residential facility and was "on the streets for about a week," as the [[Jefferson County, Texas|Jefferson County]] prosecutor stated. He revealed that, at some point, she met a 30-year-old male with a prior conviction as a drug dealer in [[Fort Bend County]], who subsequently assaulted her at his apartment in Beaumont. The assailant was arrested and pleaded guilty in September 2012 to aggravated sexual assault of a child in exchange for deferred [[probation]].<ref name=life>{{cite news |last=Horswell |first=Cindy |date=29 December 2012|title=Defendant in Cleveland gang rape case gets life sentence|url=https://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/houston/article/Defendant-in-Cleveland-gang-rape-case-gets-life-4073766.php|dead-url=no |work=[[Houston Chronicle]] |location= |archiveurl= |access-date=6 October 2018}}</ref> In 2013, the girl revealed she was pregnant, allegedly from her "15-year old boyfriend," and that they would keep the baby.<ref>{{cite news |last=|first= |date=22 May 2013|title=Girl, 14, now pregnant — was victim at age 11 of repeated gang rape|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/girl-14-pregnant-victim-age-11-repeated-gang-rape-article-1.1351930|dead-url=no |work=[[The New York Daily News]] |location= |archiveurl= |access-date=6 October 2018}}</ref>
==See also== {{columns-list|colwidth=20em| *[[Rape statistics]] *[[Rape culture]] *[[Child sexual abuse]] *[[Causes of sexual violence]] *[[Victim blaming]] *[[Laws regarding child sexual abuse]] *[[Laws regarding rape]] *[[Rape in the United States]] *[[Child abuse in the United States]] }} ==Notes== {{reflist|group=note}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{cite news |last=Solnit|first= Rebecca |author-link= Rebecca Solnit |date=24 January 2013|title=A Rape a Minute, A Thousand Corpses a Year|url=https://www.thenation.com/article/rape-minute-thousand-corpses-year/|dead-url=no |work=[[The Nation]] |location= |archiveurl= |access-date=6 October 2018}} [[Category:Violence]] [[Category:Gang rape]] [[Category:Child sexual abuse]] [[Category:Violence against women in the United States]] [[Category:Rape in the United States]] [[Category:2010 crimes in the United States]] [[Category:Crime in Texas]] [[Category:Criminal investigation]]

{{Hinduism}}
'''Abhava''' means [[non-existence]], [[negation]], [[nothing]] or absence.<ref>{{cite book|title=A Concise Dictionary of Indian Philosophy|author=John A.Grimes|publisher=SUNY Press|page=3|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=eP5p0ev3nJEC&pg=PA4&dq=abhava&hl=en&sa=X&ei=YkonUazIJIf8rAeq44CYCQ&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=abhava&f=false}}</ref> It is the negative of Bhava which means being, becoming, existing or appearance.
==Overview== Uddayana divides ''[[Padārtha]]'' (Categories) into ''[[Bhava]]'' ([[existence]]) which is real, and ''Abhava'' ([[non-existence]]) which is not real. ''[[Dravya]]'' ([[Matter|substance]]), ''[[Guṇa]]'' (quality), ''[[Karma]]'' ([[Social actions|action]]), ''Samanya'' (community or generality), ''Visesa'' (particularity or partimerity) and ''Samavaya'' ([[inherence]]) are the marks of existence. ''Abhava'' has not been categorically defined by the [[Vaisheshika]] School of [[Hindu philosophy]] but is of four kinds viz – 1) ''Pragabhava'' i.e. Prior non-existence, 2) ''Pradhvamsabhava'' i.e. Posterior non-existence, 3) ''Atyantabhava'' i.e. Absolute non-existence, and 4) ''[[Anyonyabhava]]'' i.e. Mutual non-existence.
# ''Pragabhava'' i.e. Prior non-existence, is the non-existence of an effect in its material cause before production; it has a beginning it has an end because it is destroyed by the production of the effect. Without prior non-existence there cannot be an effect. # ''Pradhvamsabhava'' i.e.Posterior non-existence, is the non-existence of an effect by its destruction; as such it has a beginning but no end i.e. it cannot be destroyed. # ''Atyantabhava'' i.e. Absolute non-existence, or absolute negation is non-existence in all times i.e. denial of an absolutely non-existent entity in all times and in all places. It is the state of absolute abstraction. # ''[[Anyonyabhava]]'' i.e. Mutual non-existence, is denial of identity between two things, which have specific nature. [[Negation]] other than mutual negation is negation of relation.
The process with which the sound value collapses into the point value of the gap existing between the first and the next syllable of the first letter of the [[Rigveda]], ''Agnim'', is ''Pradhvamsabhava'', the silent point of all possibilities within the gap is ''Atyantabhava'', the structuring dynamics of what happens within the gap ''[[Anyonyabhava]]'', and the mechanics by which the sound emerges from the point value of the gap i.e. emergence of the following syllable, is ''Pragabhava''; this mechanism is inherent in both syllables.<ref>{{cite book|title=Biographical Plays about Famous Artists|author=Daniel Meyer Dinkgrafe|publisher=Cambridge Scholars Press|page=89|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=wR50GEyHk-QC&pg=PA89&dq=abhava&hl=en&sa=X&ei=YkonUazIJIf8rAeq44CYCQ&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=abhava&f=false}}</ref>
The [[Vaisheshika]], the [[Nyaya]], the Bhatta [[Mimamsa]] and [[Dvaita]] schools hold ''Abhava'' as a distinct category. Recognised as a reality by the Nyaya school, ''Abhava'' is often stated to be the reality of the greatest moment in the pluralistic universe and is connected with [[Moksha|Mukti]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Encyclopaedia of the Hindu World Vol.1|author=Ganga Ram Garg|publisher=Concept Publishing Company|page=96|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=w9pmo51lRnYC&pg=PA96&lpg=PA96&dq=abhava&source=bl&ots=O8c7pBYtaP&sig=BfLw4cirP6wV_7Rpusu11hE2MNM&hl=en&sa=X&ei=9kInUe_KDsj5rAfSlYGwBw&sqi=2&ved=0CD0Q6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=abhava&f=false}}</ref> It is a relative word, for there can be ''abhava'' only when previously there is ''bhava''; moreover it is an event occurring in time.<ref>{{cite book|title=PrasannapadaE|author=Theodor Stcherbatsky|page=28|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=itTFXt6ZmVQC&pg=PA28&dq=abhava&hl=en&sa=X&ei=YkonUazIJIf8rAeq44CYCQ&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=abhava&f=false}}</ref> <ref>{{cite book|title=Nagarjunian Disputations|author=Thomas E. Wood|publisher=University of Hawai Press|page=180|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jHlvuNFxUlYC&pg=PA180&dq=abhava&hl=en&sa=X&ei=4FknUaqCNc6mrAfF34CoAw&ved=0CFwQ6AEwCDgK#v=onepage&q=abhava&f=false}}</ref> The Nyaya and the Siddhantin maintain that the cognition of ''abhava'' is due to perception involving special kind of contact or sense contact.<ref>{{cite book|title=Encyclopaedia of Saivism|author=Swami Parmeshwaranand|publisher=Sarup &Sons|page=40|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8ro-8reHVgoC&pg=PA40&dq=abhava&hl=en&sa=X&ei=YkonUazIJIf8rAeq44CYCQ&ved=0CEcQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=abhava&f=false}}</ref>
''Abhava'' is that unmanifest level from where the concrete ''Bhava'' arises or emerges. <ref>{{cite book|title=Mirror of Consciousness|author=Anna J. Bonshek|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass|page=194|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sT13ws7RKgYC&pg=PA194&dq=abhava&hl=en&sa=X&ei=YkonUazIJIf8rAeq44CYCQ&ved=0CFcQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=abhava&f=false}}</ref> [[Vasubandhu]] has referred to ''[[Sunyata]]'' having the characteristic of the own-being of ''abhava'', rather than a characteristic consisting of ''bhava'' which [[Sthiramati]] observes is in fact not redundant, which means ''abhava'' does not negate ''bhava''.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Buddhist Philosophy of the Middle|author=David S. Ruegg|publisher=Wisdom Publications|page=74|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LFSPAtt7OesC&pg=PA75&dq=abhava&hl=en&sa=X&ei=YkonUazIJIf8rAeq44CYCQ&ved=0CF0Q6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=abhava&f=false}}</ref> ''Abhava'' refers to particular entities and not to [[Being]] ; it is a theoretical or logical denial of the existence of some particular impossibility.<ref>{{cite book|title=Global History of Philosophy:The Axial Age Vol.1|author=John C. Plott|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass|page=163|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ODPthacrp_cC&pg=PA163&dq=abhava&hl=en&sa=X&ei=4FknUaqCNc6mrAfF34CoAw&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBTgK#v=onepage&q=abhava&f=false}}</ref> The acceptance of abhava as an independent padartha having ontological reality of its own is a peculiar feature of Indian philosophical tradition. [[Dharmakirti]] considered ''abhava'' as an ''[[anumana]]''. He had brought in the idea of imaginary presence of that whose absence was apprehended in order to explain the specificity of the absence.<ref>{{cite book|title=Contrary Thinking|author=Daya Krishna|page=125|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a44AHKGef64C&pg=PA125&dq=abhava&hl=en&sa=X&ei=K10nUY_cOsLlrAfV2oGwDA&ved=0CC0Q6AEwADgU#v=onepage&q=abhava&f=false}}</ref>

{{short description|Theosophist compendium}} {{Other uses|Akashic records (disambiguation)}} {{ref-improve|date=April 2018}} In [[Theosophy (Blavatskian)|theosophy]] and [[anthroposophy]], the '''Akashic records''' are a [[compendium]] of all human events, thoughts, words, emotions, and intent ever to have occurred in the past, present, or future. They are believed by [[Theosophy (Blavatskian)|theosophists]] to be encoded in a non-physical [[Plane (esotericism)|plane of existence]] known as the [[etheric plane]]. There are [[Anecdotal evidence|anecdotal]] accounts but there is no scientific evidence for the existence of the Akashic records.<ref>{{cite book |last= Ellwood |first= Robert S. |year=1996 |chapter= Theosophy |title= The Encyclopedia of the Paranormal |editor-last= Stein |editor-first= Gordon |editor-link= Gordon Stein |publisher= Prometheus Books |pages= 759–66 |isbn= 978-1-57392-021-6}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last= Regal |first= Brian |author-link= Brian Regal |year= 2009 |title= Pseudoscience: A Critical Encyclopedia |publisher= Greenwood |page= 29 |isbn= 978-0-313-35507-3 |quote= Other than anecdotal eyewitness accounts, there is no evidence of the ability to astral project, the existence of other planes, or of the Akashic Record.}}</ref><ref name=Drury>{{cite book | url=https://www.questia.com/read/121381643 | title=Heaven: The Rise of Modern Western Magic | publisher=Oxford University Press |last= Drury |first= Nevill | year=2011 | location=New York | pages=308 | isbn=978-0-19-975100-6}}</ref>
''[[Akasha]]'' (''{{IAST|ākāśa}}'' {{lang|sa|आकाश}}) is the [[Sanskrit]] word for '[[Aether (classical element)|aether]]' or 'atmosphere'.
==Theosophical Society== The Sanskrit term ''akasha'' was introduced to the language of theosophy through [[H. P. Blavatsky]] (1831–1891), who characterized it as a sort of life force; she also referred to "indestructible tablets of the astral light" recording both the past and future of human thought and action, but she did not use the term "akashic".<ref name="brandt_hammer">{{cite book|first1=Katharina|last1=Brandt|first2=Olav|last2=Hammer|chapter=Rudolf Steiner and Theosophy|title=Handbook of the Theosophical Current|editor1-first=Olav|editor1-last=Hammer|editor2-first=Mikael|editor2-last=Rothstein|location= Leiden, NL; Boston|publisher=Brill|year= 2013|pages= [https://books.google.com/books?id=snZRetoB9yIC&pg=PA122 122–3] |isbn= 9789004235960 |ref={{Harvid|Hammer & Rothstein|2013}}}}</ref> The notion of an akashic ''record'' was further disseminated by [[Alfred Percy Sinnett]] in his book [[Esoteric Buddhism (book)|''Esoteric Buddhism'']] (1883) when he cites [[Henry Steel Olcott]]'s ''A Buddhist Catechism'' (1881).<ref name="esoteric.buddhism">{{cite book|first=Alfred Percy|last=Sinnett|title=Esoteric Buddhism|page=127|url=https://books.google.com/?id=A_4LAAAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover&pg=PA127&dq=akasa|year=1884|edition=5th|publisher=Houghton Mifflin}}</ref> Olcott wrote that "Buddha taught two things are eternal, viz, 'Akasa' and 'Nirvana': everything has come out of Akasa in obedience to a law of motion inherent in it, and, passes away. No thing ever comes out of nothing." Olcott further explains that "Early Buddhism, then, clearly held to a permanency of records in the Akasa and the potential capacity of man to read the same, when he was evoluted to the stage of true individual enlightenment."<ref>Olcott, Henry Steel. ''A Buddhist Catechism''. London: Allen Scott and Company, 1881. [https://books.google.com/books?id=pgBOAQAAIAAJ&dq=A%20Buddhist%20catechism%20olcott&pg=PA51#v=onepage&q=akasa&f=false 51–2], [https://books.google.com/books?id=pgBOAQAAIAAJ&dq=A%20Buddhist%20catechism%20olcott&pg=PA79#v=onepage&q=akasa&f=false 79].</ref>
By [[C. W. Leadbeater]]'s [[C. W. Leadbeater#Clairvoyance|''Clairvoyance'']] (1899) the association of the term with the idea was complete, and he identified the akashic records by name as something a [[clairvoyant]] could read.<ref name="brandt_hammer" /> In his 1913 ''[[Man: whence, how and whither, a record of clairvoyant investigation|''Man: How, Whence, and Whither?'']]'', Leadbeater claims to record the history of [[Atlantis]] and other civilizations as well as the future society of [[Earth]] in the 28th century.<ref name="brandt_hammer" /><ref>{{cite book |last1= Besant |first1= Annie |last2= Leadbeater |first2= C.W. |title= Man: How, Whence, and Whither? |location= Adyar, India |year= 1913 |publisher= Theosophical Publishing House}}</ref>
[[Alice A. Bailey]] wrote in her book ''Light of the Soul'' on ''The Yoga Sutras of Patanjali – Book 3 – Union achieved and its Results'' (1927): {{quote|The akashic record is like an immense photographic film, registering all the desires and earth experiences of our planet. Those who perceive it will see pictured thereon: The life experiences of every human being since time began, the reactions to experience of the entire animal kingdom, the aggregation of the thought-forms of a [[karma|karmic nature]] (based on desire) of every human unit throughout time. Herein lies the great deception of the records. Only a trained occultist can distinguish between actual experience and those astral pictures created by imagination and keen desire.}}
==Rudolf Steiner== The [[Austrian people|Austrian]] theosophist and later founder of [[Anthroposophy]], [[Rudolf Steiner]], used the Akashic records concept mainly in a series of articles in his journal ''[[Lucifer-Gnosis]]'' from 1904 to 1908, where he wrote about [[Atlantis]] and [[Lemuria (continent)|Lemuria]], topics related to their purported history and civilisation, etc.<ref>''Aus der Akasha-Chronik''. Partial edition of the work in English: {{cite book |first= Rudolf |last= Steiner |title= The Submerged Continents of Atlantis and Lemuria, Their History and Civilization. Being Chapters From The Âkâshic Records |location= [[London]] |publisher= Theosophical Publishing Society |year= 1911}} First complete English edition: {{cite book |first= Rudolf |last= Steiner |title= Cosmic Memory |location= [[Englewood, New Jersey]] |publisher= Rudolf Steiner Publications |year= 1959}}</ref> Besides this, he used the term in the title of lectures on a ''Fifth [[Gospel]]'' held in 1913 and 1914, shortly after the foundation of the [[Anthroposophical Society]] and Steiner's exclusion from the [[Theosophical Society Adyar]].<ref> {{cite book |first= Rudolf |last= Steiner |title= The Fifth Gospel. Investigation of the Akasha Chronicle. Five lectures given in Christiania, 1913 |location= London |publisher= Rudolf Steiner Publishing |year= 1950}}</ref>
==Aquarian Gospel== [[Levi H. Dowling]]'s ''[[The Aquarian Gospel of Jesus the Christ|Aquarian Gospel of Jesus the Christ]]'' (1908) offers a version of the youth of [[Jesus Christ]] ostensibly based upon "akashic record" material.
== Popular culture == References to the ''Akashic Records'' can be found in few fantasy fictions like "[https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/32953267-evolv EvOLv]" by Ryan Sequeira and "[https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/36982571-keepers-of-the-kalachakra Keepers of the Kalachakra]" by [[Ashwin Sanghi]].

{{Infobox person | name = Albert Turner | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1936|02|29}} | birth_place = [[Marion, Alabama]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2000|04|13|1936|02|29}} | death_place = [[Selma, Alabama]] | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = Civil rights activist; politician | years_active = 1962–2000 | known_for = field secretary for [[Southern Christian Leadership Conference|SCLC]], leading [[Selma to Montgomery marches]] | notable_works = | spouse = Evelyn
(m. 19xx–2000, his death) | children = 4 (3 sons, 1 daughter) }} '''Albert Turner''' (February 29, 1936 – April 13, 2000) was an American civil rights activist and an advisor to [[Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.]]{{cite news|last1=Kelley|first1=Tina|title=Albert Turner Is Dead at 64; Strove for Civil Rights in South|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/04/15/us/albert-turner-is-dead-at-64-strove-for-civil-rights-in-south.html|accessdate=8 February 2017|work=The New York Times|date=15 April 2000}} He was Alabama field secretary for the [[Southern Christian Leadership Conference]] and helped lead [[Selma to Montgomery marches|the voting rights march from Selma to Montgomery]]; he was beaten on [[Bloody Sunday (1965)|Bloody Sunday]].{{cite news|last1=Lee|first1=Michelle Ye Hee|title=The facts about the voter fraud case that sank Jeff Sessions’s bid for a judgeship|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2016/11/28/the-facts-about-the-voter-fraud-case-that-sunk-jeff-sessionss-bid-for-a-judgeship/ |accessdate=8 February 2017|work=Washington Post|date=November 28, 2016}} ==Early life== Turner was born outside of [[Marion, Alabama]], the son of a Perry County farmer; he was the fourth of 12 children. He graduated from [[Alabama A&M]]. ==Career== Albert Turner attempted to register to vote in 1962, but despite his college education, could not pass the [[literacy test]] given.{{cite interview |subject=Albert Turner |interviewer=Thomas C. Dent |date=7 August 1991 |title=Alabama - Selma: Albert Turner Interviewee [Part 1] |url=https://digitallibrary.tulane.edu/islandora/object/tulane%3A53944 |accessdate=16 February 2017}} That incident galvanized Turner to organize local voter registration efforts and educate prospective voters about the voter registration tests. Turner was one of the marchers credited with leading the Selma to Montgomery procession in March 1965 while Dr. King attended a ceremony honoring his work in Cleveland.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=cO4rAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4wUGAAAAIBAJ&pg=4164%2C5622189 |title=Rain, Blisters Hurt: Marchers' Pace Slows Today |author= |date=23 March 1965 |newspaper=Kentucky New Era |volume=77 |number=107 |accessdate=16 February 2017 |quote=Taking King's place at the head of the line were [[John Lewis (Georgia politician)|John Lewis]], cochairman of the [[Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee]]; Albert Turner, a negro leader from Marion; attorney [[Charles Rangel|Charles Rangle [sic]]] of New York; George Fowler of the New York Commission on Human Rights; and Norman Houston, Los Angeles of the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People]].}} He served as State Director of the SCLC from 1965 to 1972.{{cite interview |subject=Albert Turner |interviewer=Thomas C. Dent |date=7 August 1991 |title=Alabama - Selma: Albert Turner Interviewee [Part 2] |url=https://digitallibrary.tulane.edu/islandora/object/tulane%3A53945 |accessdate=16 February 2017}} After the assassination of Dr. King, Turner led the mule train which bore his body to its final resting place.{{cite journal|date=March–April 1985|title=Crackdown in the Black Belt|url=http://southernchanges.digitalscholarship.emory.edu/sc07-1_1204/sc07-1_008/|journal=Southern Changes|publisher=Southern Regional Council|volume=7|pages=1–5|author=Tullos, Allen|number=1|accessdate=16 February 2017}} Turner attracted national attention in 1978 as the manager of the Southwest Alabama Farmers Cooperative Association, when he and an ex-[[moonshine]] distiller teamed up to cheaply produce ethanol for [[Common ethanol fuel mixtures|gasohol]] from corn mash.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=UQlIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=VQANAAAAIBAJ&pg=1408%2C3068664 |title=Washington merry-go-round: Moonshine power may replace fossil fuels |author=Anderson, Jack |agency=United Feature Syndicate |date=20 April 1978 |newspaper=The Morning Record |accessdate=16 February 2017}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WwAkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gWcEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2783%2C2154096 |title=Federal Still In Operation |author= |agency=AP |date=6 May 1978 |newspaper=Sarasota Herald-Tribune |accessdate=16 February 2017}} ===Voting rights activism in Alabama=== Traditionally, white voters in the [[Black Belt (region of Alabama)|Black Belt]] region of Alabama had taken advantage of absentee ballots to retain control of elected offices; even with the increased registration of black voters, white absentee nonresident voters would vote in local elections at the behest of resident relatives and friends. [[Wilcox County, Alabama|Wilcox County]] Commissioner Bobby Joe Johnson joked, "Do you know why the roads to white folks' cemeteries are paved in the Black Belt? It's so people won't get their feet wet if it rains on election day." Despite complaints of fraud, election officials failed to obtain any indictments for absentee voter fraud. When Turner went to Washington D.C. to complain about fraud to lawyers at the Justice Department, he was told the government "[couldn't] do anything ... Y'all need to learn to use the absentee-ballot process yourselves."{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/09/magazine/the-voter-fraud-case-jeff-sessions-lost-and-cant-escape.html|title=The Voter Fraud Case Jeff Sessions Lost and Can't Escape|date=9 January 2017|author=Bazelon, Emily|newspaper=The New York Times Magazine|accessdate=16 February 2017}} [[Perry County, Alabama|Perry County]] and the other counties forming the Black Belt, initially named for its soil, are some Alabama's poorest counties, and residents of the Black Belt typically travel out of their home counties for work, making it difficult to vote at local polls, which were only open in Perry County for four hours in the afternoon. In addition, many potential black voters in the Black Belt are elderly and/or illiterate due to inferior education, again limiting poll access. As a result, local civil rights organizations, including the Perry County Civic League (PCCL), began to register black voters for and assist them with absentee ballots. In 1979, Maggie Bozeman and Julia Wilder were convicted of absentee voter fraud in a 1978 election held in [[Pickens County, Alabama|Pickens County]].{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1982/02/06/pickens-county-flare-up-the-story-of-2-blacks-found-guilty/5fdc01a5-35f2-46a7-94eb-01bba7e47418/ |title=Pickens County Flare-Up: The Story of 2 Blacks Found Guilty |author=Harris, Art |date=6 February 1982 |newspaper=The Washington Post |accessdate=16 February 2017}} The verdict was reached by an all-white jury, and the pair were sentenced to four (Bozeman) and five (Wilder) years imprisonment, believed to be the strongest sentences handed out to-date for voting fraud in Alabama. The conviction was later upheld by the Alabama Supreme Court before being overturned in federal court, but the pair, known as the Carrollton Two, started to serve their sentences in January 1982 and were freed in November 1982 after spending 11 days in prison, with the balance of time served on work release in Tuskegee.{{cite news |url=http://www.upi.com/Archives/1982/11/09/Carrollton-Two-freed/8914405666000/ |title='Carrollton Two' freed |author= |date=9 November 1982 |publisher=UPI |accessdate=16 February 2017}} The initial conviction, though, depressed black voter participation in Pickens County. === The Marion Three === State district attorney Roy Johnson convened a grand jury during the fall and winter of 1982–83 to investigate PCCL-led voter assistance programs and absentee ballots, but failed to obtain an indictment. Johnson took his suspicions to Assistant Attorney General [[William Bradford Reynolds]], head of the Civil Rights Division of the Department of Justice in October 1982, asking Reynolds to deploy federal marshals to supervise elections, and Reynolds demurred, saying it was not possible under the Voting Rights Act. In the summer of 1984, US Justice Department officials promulgated a new policy to "investigate political participants who seek out the elderly, socially disadvantaged, or the illiterate, for the purpose of subjugating their electoral will,"{{cite court |litigants=Smith v. Meese |vol=821 |reporter=F.2d |opinion=1484 |court=11th Cir. |date=1987 |url=https://casetext.com/case/smith-v-meese |accessdate=17 February 2017}} applying it in a selective manner against civil rights activists seeking to register black voters in the Black Belt. At the time, Turner led the PCCL, and a rival group complained to the local district attorney that Turner and other PCCL officials were altering votes on absentee ballots.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/trumps-pick-for-attorney-general-is-shadowed-by-race-and-history/2016/12/24/1432cffa-b650-11e6-959c-172c82123976_story.html|title=Trump's pick for attorney general is shadowed by race and history|date=24 December 2016|author1=Nakashima, Ellen|author2=Horwitz, Sari|newspaper=The Washington Post|accessdate=16 February 2017}} In the 1984 election, according to Congressional testimony in 1986 from Jeff Sessions at his confirmation hearing, out of 4,000 ballots total in Perry County, 729 were absentee ballots,{{cite report |url=https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/008515911 |title=Nomination of Jefferson B. Sessions III, to be U.S. District Judge for the Southern District of Alabama: hearings before the Committee on the Judiciary, United States Senate, Ninety-ninth Congress, second session March 13, 19, 20, and May 6, 1986 / Serial No. J-99-120 |date=1987 |publisher=United States Government Printing Office |accessdate=16 February 2017}} which seemed like a disproportionately high number since more absentee ballots were cast in Perry than in Jefferson County, which had more than 45 times the number of residents of Perry County. At Sessions's suggestion, the FBI watched the Marion post office during the September 1984 primary election, where they saw the Turner, his wife Evelyn and Spencer Hogue Jr. drop off absentee ballots; election officials, under a court order, marked those envelopes and identified 75 altered ballots in the group of ballots dropped of by PCCL officials. FBI agents took the marked ballots and confronted many of the voters with allegations of "ballot tampering." Of the eighteen counties counted as part of the Black Belt, the investigation concentrated on the five counties which had posted the largest gains in black elected officials. In a later interview, Evelyn Turner explained the alterations were performed at the request of the voters, assistance permitted by state law. Nevertheless the prosecution moved forward and Turner, his wife Evelyn, and Hogue, who became known as the Marion Three, were indicted on twenty-nine counts by a [[Mobile, Alabama|Mobile]]-based federal grand jury on January 25, 1985 based on allegations of ballot tampering in the September 4, 1984 primary election.{{cite news|title=Albert Turner Sr.; 'Point Man' for King in Civil Rights Fight|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2000/apr/15/local/me-19880|accessdate=8 February 2017 |author= |agency=Associated Press |newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=15 April 2000}} The maximum punishment was 115 years in prison and $40,000 in fines. Turner's brother Robert, a lawyer who was part of the defense team for the Marion Three, alleged in 2016 that Sessions had jailed the Marion Three to send a message: "You got a person like Albert Turner that's out front, spearheading all these voter registration drives, why not put him in jail and see how many people get scared?" {{quote |text=This whole FBI investigation of absentee voting and the scheduled trials were set up to stop the political progress of black people in the Alabama Black Belt. The power structure wants to turn back the hands of time in Perry County and throughout west Alabama. I would encourage black people not to let my indictment stop them or discourage them. We need to vote in even larger numbers because they are trying to take our right to vote away again. |author=Albert Turner (1985) |source=at his trial defense }} The Marion Three were defended by a team of lawyers experienced in civil rights litigation, including Turner's brother Robert, [[J. L. Chestnut]], [[Lani Guinier]], James Liebman, [[Deval Patrick]], and [[Henry Sanders (politician)|Hank Sanders]].{{cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1985-12-11/news/8503250826_1_vote-fraud-black-leaders-justice-department|title=New South Wears 'Black Belt' In Politics|date=11 December 1985|author=Hirsley, Michael|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=16 February 2017}} During the grand jury investigation in October 1984, more than two dozen subpoenaed witnesses, many of them black senior citizens familiar with segregation-era intimidation techniques, were bused more than {{convert|160|mi}} to [[Mobile, Alabama|Mobile]] to be photographed, fingerprinted, provide handwriting samples, and testify before the federal grand jury. Grand jury records indicate that several of the questioned witnesses were so intimidated they would no longer vote in the future. The case moved to trial on June 19, 1985.{{cite journal |url=http://southernchanges.digitalscholarship.emory.edu/sc07-2_1204/sc07-2_005/ |title=Crackdown in the Black Belt: Not-So-Simple Justice |author=Tullos, Allen |journal=Southern Changes |publisher=Southern Regional Council |date=May–June 1985 |volume=7 |number=2 |pages=2–11 |accessdate=16 February 2017}} The federal jury deliberated for three hours before handing down "not guilty" verdicts for all three defendants on all charges on July 5, 1985.{{cite journal |url=http://southernchanges.digitalscholarship.emory.edu/sc07-3_1204/sc07-3_018/ |title=Crackdown in the Black Belt: On to Greene County |author=Williams, Randall |journal=Southern Changes |publisher=Southern Regional Council |date=July–August 1985 |volume=7 |number=3 |pages=2–5 |accessdate=16 February 2017}}{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2016/11/18/black-belt-voter-fraud-case-alabama-shaped-sen-jeff-sessions-career/94088186/|title=Black Belt voter fraud case in Alabama shaped Sen. Jeff Sessions' career|date=November 18, 2016|work=USA TODAY|last2=Troyan|first2=Mary|language=en|last1=Lyman|first1=Brian|accessdate=8 February 2017}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=20ogAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jqYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2236%2C1681273|title=Fraud grips Black Belt|date=12 September 2004|quote={{pad|1.0em}}'For Albert Turner [Jr.] to talk about the integrity of the election process is a damn joke,' [attorney Jim Barnes] said. 'His daddy invented voter fraud, and he's carried on the family tradition, to be blunt about it.'
{{pad|1.0em}}Albert Turner Sr., his wife, Evelyn, and [Spencer] Hogue [Jr.] were found not guilty of voter fraud charges in 1985.
{{pad|1.0em}}Prosecutors claimed the 'Marion Three,' as they came to be known, illegally obtained absentee ballots and forged the signatures of voters. The three called the investigation an attempt to manipulate black voters.|author=Kampis, Johnny|newspaper=The Tuscaloosa News|accessdate=16 February 2017}} Turner renewed his contention that the trial was instigated by freshman Senator [[Jeremiah Denton]] ([[Republican Party (United States)|R]]-[[Alabama|AL]]), who, Turner said, had the most to gain by intimidating black voters. Sessions later claimed that his team, which consisted of two lawyers, was understaffed and unprepared to tackle a "vigorous defense."{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/06/politics/marion-three-jeff-sessions/ |title=Woman prosecuted by Jeff Sessions can't forgive |author1=Zamost, Scott |author2=Griffin, Drew |author3=Devine, Curt |date=9 January 2017 |publisher=CNN Politics |accessdate=16 February 2017}} ==Later life and legacy== Turner died on April 13, 2000, while being prepared for an operation to stop abdominal bleeding. His youngest son, Albert Turner Jr., was appointed to fill Turner Sr.'s seat on the Perry County Commission after Turner Sr.'s death.{{cite news |url=http://www.montgomeryadvertiser.com/story/news/2015/07/27/al-benns-alabama-son-carries-turner-legacy/30721845/ |title=Al Benn's Alabama: Son carries on Turner legacy |author=Benn, Alvin |date=27 July 2015 |newspaper=Montgomery Advertiser |accessdate=16 February 2017}} A stretch of [[Perry County, Alabama|Perry County]] Road 45 south from Marion is named the Albert Turner Sr Memorial Highway. Perry County has also named an elementary school for Turner. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{cite web |url=http://www.crmvet.org/mem/alturner.htm |title=Albert Turner 1936-2000 |author=Hartford, Bruce |date= |publisher=Civil Rights Movement Veterans |accessdate=16 February 2017 |quote={{pad|1.0em}}[...]{{pad|1.0em}}We had not been there [in [[Brantley, Alabama]]] more than 20 minutes when a car skidded up to the cabin in a cloud of red dust. A Black woman jumped out, she was the Mayor's maid she told us. He had sent her to warn us out of town. He was calling out the mob, and we'd better stay out if we knew what was good for us.
{{pad|1.0em}}′You tell the Mayor that if he wants us, he can find us here,′ Al told her softly. He went out on the porch and sat down in an old rocking chair facing the street. Slowly he rocked back and forth, back and forth. Cars and trucks filled with hard-eyed white men, the same ones that had chased us the day before, drove at low speed past the house. They stared hard at Al and the rest of us while he rocked back and forth, back and forth. They drove by again, and again, and again, and Al just slowly rocked back and forth in that old rocking chair.}} * {{vimeo |id=117985418 |title=A Message from Albert Turner, the "Root Doctor" (excerpt from ''Street Heat'' documentary, 1989)}} * {{cite court |litigants=United States of America v. Albert Turner, et al. |vol=812 |reporter=F.2d |opinion=1552 |court=11th Cir. |date=30 March 1987 |url=http://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F2/812/1552/99769/ |accessdate=16 February 2017}} {{African-American Civil Rights Movement}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Turner, Albert (civil rights activist)}} [[Category:Civil rights activists]] [[Category:20th-century African-American activists]] [[Category:Anti-racism activists]] [[Category:1936 births]] [[Category:2000 deaths]] [[Category:Selma to Montgomery marches]] [[Category:Activists from Alabama]]

revision.text:
{{multiple image | direction = vertical | width = 200 | footer = Renderings of Antoine's necklace | image1 = Antoine's Necklace Iteration 1.png | alt1 = Antoine's necklace | caption1 = First iteration | image2 = Antoine's Necklace Iteration 2.png | alt2 = Antoine's necklace | caption2 = Second iteration }} In mathematics '''Antoine's necklace''' is a topological embedding of the [[Cantor set]] in 3-dimensional Euclidean space, whose complement is not [[simply connected]]. It also serves as a counterexample to the claim that all [[Cantor space]]s are ambiently homeomorphic to each other. It was discovered by {{harvs|txt=yes|authorlink= Louis Antoine|last=Antoine|first=Louis|year=1921}}.
==Construction==
Antoine's necklace is constructed iteratively like so: Begin with a [[solid torus]] ''A''<sup>0</sup> (iteration 0). Next, construct a "necklace" of smaller, linked tori that lie inside ''A''<sup>0</sup>. This necklace is ''A''<sup>1</sup> (iteration 1). Each torus composing ''A''<sup>1</sup> can be replaced with another smaller necklace as was done for ''A''<sup>0</sup>. Doing this yields ''A''<sup>2</sup> (iteration 2).
This process can be repeated a countably infinite number of times to create an ''A''<sup>''n''</sup> for all ''n''. Antoine's necklace ''A'' is defined as the intersection of all the iterations.
==Properties==
Since the solid tori are chosen to become arbitrarily small as the iteration number increases, the connected components of ''A'' must be single points. It is then easy to verify that ''A'' is [[closure (mathematics)|closed]], [[dense-in-itself]], and [[totally disconnected]], having the [[cardinality of the continuum]]. This is sufficient to conclude that as an abstract metric space ''A'' is homeomorphic to the Cantor set.
However, as a subset of Euclidean space ''A'' is not ambiently homeomorphic to the standard Cantor set ''C'', embedded in '''R'''<sup>3</sup> on a [[line segment]]. That is, there is no bi-continuous map from '''R'''<sup>3</sup> → '''R'''<sup>3</sup> that carries ''C'' onto ''A''. To show this, suppose there was such a map ''h'' : '''R'''<sup>3</sup> → '''R'''<sup>3</sup>, and consider a loop ''k'' that is interlocked with the necklace. ''k'' cannot be continuously shrunk to a point without touching ''A'' because two loops cannot be continuously unlinked. Now consider any loop ''j'' disjoint from ''C''. ''j'' can be shrunk to a point without touching ''C'' because we can simply move it through the gap intervals. However, the loop ''g'' = ''h''<sup>−1</sup>(''k'') is a loop that ''cannot'' be shrunk to a point without touching ''C'', which contradicts the previous statement. Therefore, ''h'' cannot exist.
Antoine's necklace was used by {{harvs|txt|last=Alexander|first=James Waddell|authorlink=James Waddell Alexander II|year=1924}} to construct '''Antoine's horned sphere''' (similar to but not the same as [[Alexander's horned sphere]]).
==See also== * [[Cantor set#Cantor dust|Cantor dust]] * [[Knaster–Kuratowski fan]] * [[Sierpinski carpet]] * [[Whitehead manifold]]
==References== *{{citation|first=Louis|last=Antoine|authorlink=Louis Antoine|title=Sur l'homeomorphisme de deux figures et leurs voisinages |journal= Journal Math Pures et appl.|volume=4|year=1921|pages=221–325}} *{{citation|title=Remarks on a Point Set Constructed by Antoine |authorlink=James Waddell Alexander II|first=J. W.|last= Alexander |journal= [[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America]] |volume=10|issue= 1|year= 1924|pages= 10–12 |doi=10.1073/pnas.10.1.10|pmid=16576769|pmc=1085501|jstor=84203|bibcode=1924PNAS...10...10A}} *{{citation|title=Antoine's Necklace or How to Keep a Necklace from Falling Apart |first= Beverly L. |last=Brechner|first2= John C.|last2= Mayer |journal= The College Mathematics Journal|volume= 19|issue= 4|year= 1988|pages= 306–320 |doi=10.2307/2686463|jstor=2686463}} *{{cite book |last=Pugh |first=Charles Chapman |date=2002 |title=Real Mathematical Analysis |doi=10.1007/978-0-387-21684-3 |publisher=Springer New York |pages=106–108 |isbn=9781441929419}}
